CatDescriptText: Mr. Charles Cutrary, trucker, Homewood and Mrs. Emma Chatman, Homewood, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, September 23, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you believe there is such a "social" classification as "Negro society?"  If so, on what do you believe it is based? Do you think such a basis is valid?" Mr. Cutray's answer reads: "...Oh yes, I don't think there is however, in this industrial town.  The people just don't have the time to get together, because they are too busy earning a living.  Society is based on money and better living, higher standards of living, and I think these are pretty good reasons for this society."  Mrs. Chatman's answer reads: "...Yes, I do.  And it's based mostly on education ,and I think that this is good."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Charles Cutrary wearing moustache, button down collared shirt with breast pockets, and hat, standing in front of store; Portrait of Emma Chatman wearing eyeglasses and houndstooth top with three buttons and wide collar, standing in front of light colored wall
